turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: So what do we do -- nothing?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: We bring her in for questioning.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: What is all this "Nick" stuff -- Nick would you like a cigarette. Nick can you give me a ride.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She didn't ask me for the ride. She asked anybody.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: And you volunteered.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Now what?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: What now what? Now nothing.  She passed the polygraph.  That's it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She knew she could beat it.  That's why she asked to take it.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: How the fuck do you know?  What is it with you and this broad anyway?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Come on, Phil.  You're not gonna let this slide.  What about her parents?  What about what else she's published?  At least we should get the stuff to see if we find anything else that's an amazing real-life coincidence.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Her parents died in an accident. I don't care what else she's written.  What are you -- a book critic?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How did they die?  Was there an investigation?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: How you're saying she killed her parents?  Did she kill Bobby Vasquez, too?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Fuck you, Phil.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Fuck you, too Nick.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Gus -- go over to Berkeley. Harrigan -- find out what else she's published.  Andrews -- get the files on her parents' accident. Carbon Beth on everything.  I want some psychological input on this Andrews and Harrigan go; Nick is left there with Gus.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: I'll ask you once, Nick -- for the record did you kill him?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: I.A.'s going to talk to you more about Nilsen.  They're handling the investigation, we're not. Stay in touch with Dr. Gardner, it'll help on the evaluation.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She killed him.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Beth?  Now you've got Beth killing people?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Catherine Tramell.  It's part of her game.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: First you've got her buying your file.  Now you've got her killing Nilsen.  Forget her, willya?  Go someplace.  Sit in the sun.  Get away from this goddamn fog.  Get her out of your system.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You don't but it, do you?  She knew nobody would but it.  She knew I'd say she did it.  And she knew nobody would buy it.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Tell me again.  I want to hear you say it again.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It was an accident.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: You're driving around North Beach for no particular reason and this car won't get out of the way --

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't think she meant to go off the hill, do you?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Don't fuck with me, Nick.  I don't need a reason to put your ass in a sling.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: You knew her, didn't you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Gus and I talked to her at Tramell's house.  All we did was write her name down.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: I told you to stay away from Tramell.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah.  But you didn't tell me to stay away from her car.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: She's a suspect.

turns.speaker: TALCOTT
turns.text: On what basis?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Catherine Tramell.  Age 30.  No priors, no convictions.  Double major, magnum cum laude, Berkeley, 1980.  Literature and Psychology. Daughter, sole survivor -- Marvin and Elaine Tramell, killed in a boating accident, 1978, Catherine Tramell sole heir.  Estimated assets $110 million.

turns.speaker: TALCOTT
turns.text: She's got enough money to burn this whole department down.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: She was the last person seen with the guy -- I'll take the responsibility.

turns.speaker: TALCOTT
turns.text: It's yours.

turns.speaker: TALCOTT
turns.text: We know you're not stupid, Ms. Tramell.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Maybe that's what you're counting on to get you off the hook.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We're sorry to disturb you, we'd like to ask you some --

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Are you vice?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why do you think he's dead?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: You wouldn't be here otherwise, would you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: I'm Roxy.  I'm her -- friend.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How old was she when this happened?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Fourteen.  We seal juvenile records until they're deceased.  That's why you didn't find it in your computer.

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Anderson.  Jack W. Donald M.  I'm sorry.  No Lisa.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Did you check all four years?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Yes I did.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Can you check again?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: No Lisa Anderson, detective.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Can there be some mistake?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Only if you're making it.

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: He died -- about five or six years ago.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: He was shot.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: My name is Jean Michel Basquiat. Have you heard of me?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: No. Should I have?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I'm a painter, too.

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: Really. Huh. Too bad.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Hey  it's the big A.M..

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: Rene's been telling me about your work.

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: Is this finished yet?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: When's your show?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Not sure. How was yours?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: I haven't decided yet.  Rene, you wanna come over to the studio tomorrow. I wanna make a painting of you.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: I like the one with the dragon's heads a lot. But the black one's filled up with too many heads...  I'd take some of them out.  I think you're painting too fast. I wouldn't put in so many heads. Let it breathe a bit.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: It's always how you would do it. This is my version.

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: You're right. It's your version. You should come over to the studio sometime.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Why, so you could humiliate me?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: No, I wanted to make a painting of you.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Naa..

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: Let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: See ya in an hour.  So what do you think?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: This is painted on a backdrop from the Kabuki theater in Japan. I painted it after Joseph Beuys died. A rebirth painting. I felt like he could've painted it, or maybe someone else was painting it instead of me. The Chinese calligraphers used to change their name mid-career so they could start over as someone else..

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Do you ever get sick of it?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: Of what?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: The whole thing  painting.

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: No. It's one of the few times I feel good. I used to have to go to work and cook every day. That I got sick of.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: What about the shit they write?

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: You're asking me this because of the 'lapdog' remark. I read that. The person that wrote that has the compassion of a housefly. That's your enemy, not your audience. Your audience hasn't even been born yet. It's a lie that art is popular. The only thing popular about it is that it's written about in newspapers. I'm surprised when anybody comes to my openings. There're about ten people on the planet who know anything about painting, and Andy's one of them.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I haven't felt like talking to him since that thing came out.

turns.speaker: ALBERT MILO
turns.text: As long as I've known Andy, he's never asked me for anything except to speak to you about getting off drugs. He's painted my picture, we've eaten dinner in God knows how many places together. But he doesn't care about me. He cares about you. You're the only person he cares about. He's your friend. Fuck that article. You want a toasted bagel with cream cheese?

turns.speaker: JACK MILO
turns.text: Nixon lives in Saddle River, New York.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Saddle River's in New Jersey.

turns.speaker: JACK MILO
turns.text: Saddle River, New York!

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: It's in New Jersey.

turns.speaker: JACK MILO
turns.text: New York.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: I think it's in New Jersey.

turns.speaker: JACK MILO
turns.text: It's in New York.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Oh, I didn't know that.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: You wanna buy some ignorant art? Ten bucks.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Ignorant art?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah... Like  stupid, ridiculous, crummy art.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Ohhh. That's new. That sounds good.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Ten bucks apiece.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: I can give you five. You didn't do very much to these.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: You don't even work on your stuff!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Andy, man, thanks for coming. I'd like to paint your jacket.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: My jacket? Gee, great...  Your show looks great. Quite a turnout. You look great. You kids. You drink red wine with fish. You can do anything! Make paintings in the basement of your gallery? First time I've heard of that!

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Jean Michel, this is Mary Boone. She's got the great new gallery.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah, I met her already.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I wish they'd quit writing this shit about me.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: That's good. At least they're interested.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Everybody's paying top dollar for scraps of paper, refrigerator doors  anything with a SAMO tag on it.  The other day, I just wanted a pack of cigarettes, so I did a drawing and sold it for two bucks. A week later this gallery calls me up: "Somebody's offering us the drawing. Should we buy it for five thousand?"

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Wow... Stop giving them away.  I got an invitation to model for Comme de Garcons... You wanna do it with me?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah  I'd do that... You could teach me.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Gee. I don't need to. You're a natural. You should sign up with my modeling agent.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Cool.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: My dog, Archie... I woke up with flea bites... Creepy. I ran out and bought flea collars. They work really well.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Let's leave this town and go someplace. Some island.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Let's go to the Carnegie Museum. They have the world's most famous sculptures all in these giant plaster replicas. It's really great. It's in Pittsburg.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Ouch..

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: That girl looks just like my old girlfriend Gina.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Do you still love her?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah. I really blew it. I still think about her.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Well, have you asked her to come back?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: What's with the wigs?

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: I'm going to send them to my friends for Christmas presents.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: You think those are good presents? Who wants an old wig?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Piss painting?

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: I wanted to make a few more of these. Frank's been drinking this Mexican beer. It makes a good green.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: How come you're not peeing on them yourself?

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: I don't like beer.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: That was my favorite part!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: We can do better. It needed more white.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I don't even have any friends anymore besides you. And everyone says "Warhol? That death-warmed over person on drugs? He's just using you."

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Gee. You shouldn't take it so seriously, Jean. That's why you can't stop taking drugs. You always think people don't like you. Everyone likes you.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: People are only interested in you because you're famous, not because they know a fuckin' thing about your work.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Bruno called. In Europe, people are saying you're gonna die from drugs. They think they can cash in on your death.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: When I was poor, everybody doubted I could make it. When I got rich, everyone said, `yeah, but he'll never keep it up.' Now everyone says `he's killing himself.' So I clean up, and then they say `Look. His art's dead.' I don't take drugs, anyway. I'm healthy now.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: After the show we should take a nice long vacation. Maybe go to Hawaii. That's what I'm gonna do. I'm going to give up painting and start playing music again. I wanna sing.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: That would be a pity because you're a real painter.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: Annina Nosei.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: Is Jean Michel here?

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: These are great.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Aren't they?

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: How much for these five?

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: You should talk to him about this.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: I'm interested in showing Jean's work.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: I really think you should talk to him about this.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: You haven't been by lately.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: I'd love to see some more of your work... Where's your studio?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: You name it, I paint there.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: Well, I don't want to get mugged on a Bowery street corner. Maybe I could find a place for you to work. Take my card.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: You want a drink?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: How about right now?

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: Tom and Cynthia Kruger.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: Jean, your parents are here.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Hi Dad. Hi Nora.

turns.speaker: ANNINA NOSEI
turns.text: It's great that people are interested, but if anyone's going to buy anything, I'll handle it for you. Everything goes through the gallery, even if they come to your studio.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ARTIST #2
turns.text: Chill, man! Be cool! This isn't even my apartment!

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Oh man, you a FINE nigga! You know that?

turns.speaker: ARTIST #2
turns.text: Cut it out, man! And don't be callin' me that shit!

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Who did this?  Who did this?

turns.speaker: ARTIST #2
turns.text: I don't know. I told you, this isn't my apartment.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Naaaa. Poor thing has a little dick.

turns.speaker: ARTIST #2
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: Just look at him.  Little silver thingies on his cowboy boots? Honey, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: MOTHAFUCKAH!

turns.speaker: ARTIST #2
turns.text: That's the same guy who did this painting.

turns.speaker: RENE
turns.text: I know that. Don't let him get away.

turns.speaker: BRUNO
turns.text: It doesn't matter how much you worked on them. It matters how much you can get for them.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I can get ten.

turns.speaker: BRUNO
turns.text: You shouldn't have put it in the show. This is the one I absolutely have to have. I really love it.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Sure, ok..

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Do you think I could borrow your limousine? I'll get it back to you in an hour.

turns.speaker: BRUNO
turns.text: It's OK. Just have him bring you to dinner at Mr. Chow's later. We'll be there.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: B.B. It's me  Jean! What's the matter? No snow in Switzerland this year?

turns.speaker: BRUNO
turns.text: I didn't see you.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BRUNO
turns.text: You haven't heard? Andy's dead.

turns.speaker: MARY BOONE
turns.text: I hear your show was sold out already. There's a very important collector who's interested in some of your works.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Bring him over sometime. I have some other stuff to show him.

turns.speaker: MARY BOONE
turns.text: Jean Michel... Crawling from the wreckage?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I need a dealer.

turns.speaker: MARY BOONE
turns.text: You have a bunch of them, don't you? Albert Milo walks in from another room.

turns.speaker: MARY BOONE
turns.text: Bruno spoke to me already. We could talk about it.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I'm here.

turns.speaker: MARY BOONE
turns.text: OK. I'll be at your studio Thursday three o'clock.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: What is it that gets you out of bed in the morning?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I hate this. Turn that off.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: ... Can you... decipher this for us?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Decipher?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Yes. What do they... stand for?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: They're just words.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Yes, I understand  but where do you take them from?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Where? Do you ask Miles where he got that note from? Where do you take your words from?  Everywhere.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: What are they?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Leeches. A long list of leeches.  It looks good like that.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Hmmm. And 'Parasites.'  You seem to be a Primal Expressionist.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: You mean like an ape?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: A primate?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Well, you said that.  You've got a lot of references from Leonardo da Vinci, don't you?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Oh, that's a "Leonardo's Greatest Hits" painting. You like it?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Yes, but as a black painter 

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I use a lot of colors  not only black.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I'm not black.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: You're not?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Not what?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Not black.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: No, I'm Haitian-Puerto Rican.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Yes, yes... Let's talk about that.... your roots... Your father is from Haiti, isn't he?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Hmmmm. Interesting. And when you grew up were there any primitives hanging in your home?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: We don't hang them at home, y'know  just in the streets..

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: I see..  And... How do you respond to being called  hmmm...   yes, "the pickaninny of the art world."

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Who said that?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Why, that's from Time Magazine.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: No, he said I was the Eddie Murphy of the art world. He said the Eddie Murphy.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Is it true that your mother resides in a mental institution?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Or rather, do you think you're being exploited or are you yourself exploiting the white image of the black artist from the ghetto?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Are those the only two possibilities?  You wanna French fry?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: OK. One last thing. Is there any anger in you? Any anger in your work?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Should there be?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Tell me about it. What are you angry about?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Would you like to see the wine list?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Chateau Latour '64, please.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Basquiat.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: See that table over there? I'd like to pay their bill.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah, just put their bill on my tab.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Very well.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Paint it out.

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text: Out?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah... Maybe just his arms.  Put some Cerulean Blue there.

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text: It's Andy again.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Still not here.

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text:  In this corner?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah..

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text: You want me to put it here?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Use your fucking instinct.

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text: It's Maria Portos. What should we do?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Why don't you try letting her in, Steve  I mean Shenge.

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text: Get up. She won't buy anything if she sees me working on it!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Wanna bet? If you show too much respect for people with money, they don't have respect for you.

turns.speaker: SHENGE
turns.text: Blue? Where?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: What's wrong with you today?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Hey  Willie Mays.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Willie Mays.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: The Devil, man. Rene Ricard. Art critic  writes for Artforum. People read him. Tell him who you are..

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Who am I?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: SAMO.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Oh yeah..

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: "She loves me. Oh yeah she loves me! She loooooooves me, Oh yeah she loves me!" Bring me some chicken, baby!

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Would you shut the fuck up? You hear what I'm doing?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah man. I'm jealous. You're always great, Benny.  "Her name is G-I-N-A Gina And she lo-oooves me." I did say chicken!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I knew I left these somewhere. One of these'll send your kids to college someday.  Here  I made this for you.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Thanks.  Your dad called again  something about a job.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: You got a date already?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: We're getting married. She said she could tell I was a great artist  she could see it in my eyes. She said she wanted to be by my side and have inter-racial babies with me.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Come on, Jean. Get rid of your cigarette. Concentrate.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I am... On Gina.  Fuck  I didn't think we were actually gonna do this.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Concentrate on the ball. Shoot.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: You're shattering all my myths.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Your people.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Oh  you mean black people!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Whatever. Famous. To where you can do your stuff all day without thinking about anything else.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Ummm... Four years. Six to get rich.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Famous people are usually pretty stupid. You're too smart. You'd get bored to death. You don't wanna be like John Henry  fighting the machine. Just do what you do. It's about integrity. Follow your heart.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Who's John Henry?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Oh man! Folklore guy  worked on the railroad. Y'know, pounding in spikes and laying down track. Then one day they invented a machine to do it. And he says "Fuck that, I'm a MAN" and he challenges the machine to a race to lay down a mile of track. It takes two days. Neck and neck the whole time. They get right to the end, and he beats it by one spike.  Got a cigarette?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: So then what?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: He drops dead! See? Just do your shit like you do it! Your friends like you, you get laid, everyone walks by, sees your stuff everywhere. It's good. What else do you want?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: What're you doing? You're doing something.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: He's the best painter in the world. I'm gonna give him one of these.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Don't give him anything, man. Your art's worth a lot. Trade. That's what real artists do with each other. Besides, he'll just use you. He's famous for that.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Check you later, man.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Hi Gina.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Willie Mays!!! Willie Mays!!!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Come on in!

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: We got beat.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: For real?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: You gonna carry that around all night?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Yeah... I'll paint on it.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: What's the rush, John Henry?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I ain't John Henry.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: What's your fuckin' problem, anyway?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: I don't really have any problems.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Good. What do you have?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: What's your fuckin' problem? You get a girlfriend and a little attention and then start acting all uppity with me.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: 'Uppity?' Like as in 'uppity nigger?'

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: That's not how I meant it.  For all you know, you might just be a flash in the pan! You can never tell.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Hey fuck you! I deserve this shit. You're just jealous 'cause it ain't happening to you!

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: She's good.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I guess it was a long time ago.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Come on, let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Sit down! You're gonna fall out!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Me fall? Let's get some drugs!

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: Drugs??!

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Medicine, man! Like health food. I'm taking care of my health!

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: No, don't tell me  you just got fired by your crazy boss.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I guess you did.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Guess I just got sick of him.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Can I walk you home?

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: I think I could do that alone.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Have you been camping? You could use a scrub.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I'm clean. Smell me. I always smell good. I don't know why, I just do!

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: You do! You definitely do.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Just come to the Mudd Club on Friday.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: I don't go there. Too many party girls.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Party girls? Can I call you?

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Yeah, if you have any dimes left. 477- 0496.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: I thought you hated this place?

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: I do.  I just said that. I was never here before. I actually like it.

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: Wanna go get some breakfast?

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: A friend of mine offered me a job doing a little work installing a show in a gallery. He's an electrician. I was supposed to be there an hour ago.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: Basquiat, those are my best clothes!!! What are you doing?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: C'mon, baby, I painted them for you. They're beautiful now.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: I'm going to my parents this weekend. What am I going to wear?  How could you do that to me?

turns.speaker: BASQUIAT
turns.text: ... I'll buy you some new ones.

turns.speaker: GINA
turns.text: You don't have any fucking money..
